org.zoolu.util

Class Timer

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.zoolu.util.Timer
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    VirtualTimer

    public class Timer
extends java.lang.Object
    A Timer is a simple object that fires the TimerListener.onTimeout(Timer) method when the time expires. Timer has to be explicitly started, and can be halted before it expires.

    A timer may run is 'daemon' mode or 'non-daemon' mode.
    In 'daemon' mode, if all program threads terminate, the timer terminates silently, without firing the corresponding timeout callback.
    Conversely, in 'non-daemon' mode, the program terminates only when the timer expires (or it is explicitly halted).

    • Constructor Detail

      • Timer

        public Timer(long millisecs,
             int nanosecs,
             TimerListener listener)
        Creates a new timer.

        The timer is not automatically started. You need to call the start() method.

        Parameters:
        millisecs - expiration time in milliseconds
        nanosecs - 0-999999 additional nanoseconds before the timer expires
        listener - timer listener

      • start

        public void start()
        Starts the timer.

      • start

        public void start(boolean daemon_mode)
        Starts the timer.
        Parameters:
        daemon_mode - whether running in 'daemon' mode In 'daemon' mode, when all other threads terminate, the program also ends regardless the timer was still running, and no timeout callback is fired. In 'non-daemon' mode, the program ends only when all active timers have expired or explicitly halted.

      • isRunning

        public boolean isRunning()
        Whether the timer is running.
        Returns:
        true if it is running

      • halt

        public void halt()
        Stops the Timer. The method TimerListener.onTimeout(Timer) of the timer listener will not be fired.
